Award.AbstractNarration: This project will continue an ongoing program of astrometric (positional) observations of Near-Earth asteroids (NEAs). Astrometric follow-up of new observations is essential in order to determine orbits and recover the objects at future observing opportunities; over 60% of NEAs newly discovered in 2008 and 2009 were subsequently lost due to the lack of adequate follow-up. The Principal Investigator and students supported by this project will perform astrometric measurements using the University of Hawaii 2.24-meter telescope and other telescopes on Mauna Kea. The telescopes and specialized techniques used enable this team to observe fainter objects, with greater positional accuracy, and with better access to the south celestial hemisphere than other groups. They will adapt the newest and most accurate astrometric reference catalog, the PPMXL catalog, for use in NEA astrometry and provide this customized catalog to the community. Improvements will be made to their data processing pipeline to speed the process and enable more positional measurements per object. Finally, the group will plan and carry out measurements of physical characteristics, including shapes, albedos and colors, of selected objects that are possible candidates for human exploration. Accurate NEA astrometry is most critical for the tracking of potentially hazardous asteroids that could collide with Earth; the project thus has broad impacts on impacts. This has implications for Earth-science questions, such as how Earth acquired its water, as well on strategies for mitigating the impact hazard. The project will educate graduate students in observational techniques and in Solar System dynamics; these students, in turn, will have the opportunity to mentor high school students in using the Falukes educational telescope on Haleakala for asteroid research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent decades, the general public has witnessed a growing awareness of the impact hazard posed by asteroids on the larger planets of our solar system.  Research suggested that the dinosaurs were wiped out by the impact of a 6-mile-wide asteroid on the Earth.  But that was 65 million years ago.  Could it happen now?  Then we watched in awe as the many fragments of comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 left Earth-sized blemishes in the atmosphere of Jupiter.  A little over a decade later, the asteroid 2008 TC3 was seen incoming, and it showered northern Sudan with meteorites.  Only a few years after that, over a thousand people in Chelyabinsk were injured by flying glass, shattered by the sonic boom created by the impact of a small asteroid with the Earth.  The impact threat is real, though fortunately for human life on Earth, the larger the impactor, the fewer there are out there, so the less frequent the impact.  Nevertheless, Congress felt compelled to have astronomers find these threatening objects, track them to refine their orbits so that we can compute with confidence whether they represent an impact threat in the foreseeable future, and characterize them so that we would have a better idea what to do if we were unfortunate enough to find one that could threaten a portion of the population on Earth.

This project was primarily concerned with the tracking aspect, refining the orbits of near-Earth asteroids so that we could reliably predict their future paths.  Our goal was to track each new discovery long enough until the possibility of an Earth impact within the next century could be eliminated.  That happened over 600 times during the life of the project.  (The work continues, though now funded by NASA.)  Near-Earth asteroids tend to be discovered when they pass close to the Earth, which makes them brighter.  However, as they recede from the vicinity of the Earth, they fade, making them harder to see.  In particular, they fade below the detection thresholds of the survey telescopes used to find them in the first place.  It takes targeted observations with larger telescopes to continue tracking them, and during the lifetime of this project, we published almost 15000 positional observations of asteroids seen during these targeted follow-up exposures.  Roughly half of this number was due to an augmented effort funded by NASA, in response to the growing number of near-Earth objects being discovered by the sky surveys as they improved their facilities, and the fact that too many potentially hazardous objects were being lost due to insufficient follow-up.  But the funding from NSF was responsible for the other half of the overall effort.  Roughly 70 percent of our observations were made when the asteroids were too faint for the survey telescopes to reach, and were therefore essential to the orbit refinement process.

The generally excellent observing conditions afforded by the Mauna Kea Observatory site in Hawaii also enabled us to produce positional observations of extremely high quality, and they represent the state-of-the-art in the tracking of near-Earth objects with ground-based telescopes.  Our positional accuracy was typically about 0.1 arcseconds, which is approximately the diameter of a dime as seen from 20 miles away.

We also helped to characterize some of the physical properties of these asteroids.  When our measurements of the reflected light from an asteroid surface are combined with measurements of the heat emitted from an asteroid made by an infrared telescope (such as the WISE spacecraft, which surveyed the entire sky at infrared wavelengths in 2010), we can measure the reflectivity of the asteroid surface materials, which contains clues as to the chemical composition of the rock.  Some of the smallest near-Earth objects can exhibit departures from motion controlled purely by gravity alone due to the pressure on sunlight falling on their surfaces.  Positional observations of the highest quality, such as ours, can detect that departure from purely gravitation motion, and we can then estimate the bulk density of the asteroid.  More often then not, the density estimate is slightly less than that of water, which indicates that the rock is not solid, but rather highly porous.  Such information about asteroids is of critical importance when designing a method to deflect a hazardous asteroid, if one is found to be on an Earth impacting trajectory.

But the work is not done.  Population studies indicate that there are many thousands more of these objects out there, waiting to be found.  Reassuringly, we now know where almost all of the largest objects are (the ones large enough to produce a repeat of the event that wiped out the dinosaurs), but there are valid concerns about smaller objects that can produce regional damage on the Earth, and it will take many more years of continued work to ease those concerns.
